text: The Savannah River Site Citizens Advisory Board is a public volunteer board and its
label: BODY

text: mission is to study the issues and provide informed, and timely recommendations,
label: BODY

text: from the public’s perspective, to the Department of Energy concerning Environmental
label: BODY

text: Management work at SRS in the areas of environmental restoration, waste  manage-
label: BODY

text: ment, and related activities.
label: BODY

text: The CAB Says “Thank you” and Farewell to Six CAB Members
label: BODY

text: The CAB Attends an H-Canyon and L-Area Tour at SRS
label: BODY

text: I want to thank each of you for your service to the CAB. We have recently been advised that
label: BODY

text: Emile Bernard, the Chair of the Waste Management Committee, will no longer be able to con-
label: BODY

text: tinue as a CAB member. He has been an involved and vibrant member and we will really miss
label: BODY

text: him. Along with Emile, we will be losing three members who have served their six-year term
label: BODY

text: limits. These members  include:
label: BODY

text: Judy Greene-McLeod, who most recently served as the CAB Vice Chair and who has
label: BODY

text: served as Chair and member of the Waste Management Committee, has had considerable
label: BODY

text: professional experience at the Savannah River Ecology Laboratory. She has been able to
label: BODY

text: direct many CAB inquiries when we delved into biological and environmental issues. She has
label: BODY

text: been a thoughtful, engaged, and active member, and will be sorely missed.
label: BODY

text: Dr. Kuppuswamy Jayaraman, also known as Dr. J, has served as Chair of the Facilities
label: BODY

text: Disposition &Site Remediation Committee and as a member of the Strategic & Legacy Man-
label: BODY

text: agement Committee. As a professor, Dr. J has brought some of that demeanor and rigor to
label: BODY

text: the CAB. He frequently makes thoughtful and insightful comments that makes us stop to re-
label: BODY

text: flect and take a more in-depth look. His contribution has been significant. Everyone will miss Dr. J, a real contrib-
label: BODY

text: utor.
label: BODY

text: Alex Williams has served on several committees including Nuclear Materials and Waste Management. Mr. Wil-
label: BODY

text: liams leads the CAB in the Pledge of Allegiance at the start of Full Board meetings. He is retired from the Army
label: BODY

text: and has brought that experience to the CAB. He is quick with pleasant and humorous comments that make the
label: BODY

text: meetings go along just a little bit better. It is always difficult to lose such a personable and upbeat person.
label: BODY

text: The Board had 20 committee meetings in 2011, in addition to six Full Board meetings and a two day Education &
label: BODY

text: Process Session. I and various other members have attended and made comments to the Blue Ribbon Committee, a
label: BODY

text: DNFSB public meeting, two Environmental Justice meetings, and an NRC public meeting. In addition, I have repre-
label: BODY

text: sented the Board at two Site Specific Advisory Board Chairs meetings, and in a meeting with the United Kingdom
label: BODY

text: Nuclear Decommissioning Authority personnel on a Site visit to SRS. At the beginning of this year we focused the
label: BODY

text: CAB on two areas: giving more CAB input to the DOE and achieving more public involvement. We are beginning to
label: BODY

text: see real gains, and I thank you for your continued interest and involvement.
label: BODY

text: At the CAB’s recent Education & Process Session, the CAB discussed a number of issues such as our approach to
label: BODY

text: committee meetings, including attendance, and “CAB Position Statements.” The CAB felt that position statements will
label: BODY

text: help it summarize its message and views on any given topic in a clear and concise way. The CAB has also spent
label: BODY

text: considerable time on increasing its interaction with the public, and will be continuing to work on a number of ideas,
label: BODY

text: such as the Speakers Bureau. With the Speaker’s Bureau, we are actively seeking audiences where we can relay
label: BODY

text: who we are and what the CAB does. Overall, the Education & Process Session was very productive.
label: BODY

text: While we seem to be making gains, we will also be faced with a lot of challenges as we go into 2012. SRS does not
label: BODY

text: appear to be getting severe cuts in 2012, but they may loom on the horizon. Overall, the Site continues to make pro-
label: BODY

text: gress on cleanup and that point is worthy of comment. Thanks to each of you for making this year so successful!
label: BODY

text: Message from the Chair– Dr. Donald N. Bridges, CAB Chair
label: BODY

text: The Savannah River Site (SRS) Citizens Advisory Board (CAB) extends a big “thank you” to everyone that helped make this newslet-
label: BODY

text: ter possible. Thank you to all the CAB members who presented ideas and articles for the newsletter, to all the presenters and manag-
label: BODY

text: ers who make Full Board and Committee meetings great, to the Board’s agency liaisons, and to the Department of Energy for contin-
label: BODY

text: ued support. We, the members of the SRS CAB, serve a very important role for DOE and our communities.
label: BODY

text: The Board Beat is published semiannually by the SRS CAB, with publications in November and May. It is distributed primarily by
label: BODY

text: email. Content is provided by Board members and the CAB Support Team.  To subscribe to the Board Beat, submit your  request,
label: BODY

text: with name and email address, to srscitizensadvisoryboard@srs.gov
label: BODY

text: If you’re interested in learning more about what we do, or think you would like to apply for membership, please check out our website
label: BODY

text: at: http://cab.srs.gov
label: BODY

text: Contact us at 803-952-7884 (800-249-8155) or via email at srscitizensadvisoryboard@srs.gov
label: BODY

text: Chair Donald N. Bridges
label: BODY

text: shares a laugh with the
label: BODY

text: CAB during the Educa-
label: BODY

text: tion & Process Session.
label: BODY

text: The Environmental Management Site-Specific Advisory Board
label: BODY

text: (EMSSAB) Chairs’ Meeting is an opportunity for all of the
label: BODY

text: EMSSAB chairs to meet with DOE Headquarters to discuss
label: BODY

text: “site-specific” and shared topics of interest. The meetings are
label: BODY

text: held bi-annually and usually rotate among eight DOE field of-
label: BODY

text: fices. The last meeting was scheduled to be held at the Neva-
label: BODY

text: da National Security Site in April of this year; however, follow-
label: BODY

text: ing Federal funding delays, was not held until June. (See arti-
label: BODY

text: cle below) As a result, this impacted the schedule for the next
label: BODY

text: meeting at the Paducah site.
label: BODY

text: It was decided, in coordination with DOE Headquarters, that
label: BODY

text: the meeting would be held, for the first time, via video telecon-
label: BODY

text: ferencing.
label: BODY

text: Cate Alexander, Designated Federal Officer of the EMSSAB, opened the meeting and introduced Dave
label: BODY

text: Huizenga, Acting Assistant Secretary for Environmental Management (EM) who provided an update on
label: BODY

text: Environmental Management. He informed the group that because of known budget cuts, it is important to
label: BODY

text: get SSAB input on priorities. Regarding waste disposition strategies, he said EM was looking at the Waste
label: BODY

text: Isolation Pilot Plant for Greater than Class C waste and wants input on how to deal with waste streams.
label: BODY

text: Each site was given an opportunity to ask questions of Mr. Huizenga and then provided their respective
label: BODY

text: site top three, board-perceived issues. Participating in the teleconference for the Savannah River Site CAB
label: BODY

text: was CAB Chair, Don Bridges along with several CAB members. The top three issues (plus one additional
label: BODY

text: issue) presented for the CAB were 1) concern for the Receipt of Additional Research Reactor Spent Nu-
label: BODY

text: clear Fuel and Continued Long Term Storage of Existing Inventories with No Known, Approved Disposition
label: BODY

text: Path; 2) the need to Effectively Utilize H-Canyon; 3) a need to Prioritize Site Activities in View of Likely
label: BODY

text: Budget Cuts; and 4) since the cancellation of Yucca Mountain, a concern for a Lack of a Federal Reposito-
label: BODY

text: ry for Nuclear Waste Disposition and Storage.
label: BODY

text: EM SSAB First Chairs’ Teleconference Successful
label: BODY

text: Several CAB members attended the EM SSAB
label: BODY

text: Chairs’ teleconference.
label: BODY

text: EM SSAB Chairs’ Meeting Held in Las Vegas on June 15-16
label: BODY

text: The Chairs and Vice Chairs of the Environmental Management Site Specific
label: BODY

text: Advisory Board (EM SSAB) meet bi-annually to discuss issues and concerns
label: BODY

text: that  occur within  the advisory components situated at eight DOE Sites. The
label: BODY

text: EM SSAB is a federally chartered community-based advisory board that
label: BODY

text: works to provide the Department of Energy-Environmental Management
label: BODY

text: (DOE-EM) with recommendations  and advice on cleanup and other activities.
label: BODY

text: On June 15-16, 2011, the representatives from these boards met in Las Ve-
label: BODY

text: gas, Nevada, for its spring meeting.
label: BODY

text: The meeting was open to the public, with scheduled public comment periods.
label: BODY

text: Dr. Donald N. Bridges, SRS CAB Chair, and Dr. Gerald Wadley, SRS CAB
label: BODY

text: Strategic & Legacy Management Chair, attended the meeting.
label: BODY

text: The various site Chairs presented the three top site issues according to their
label: BODY

text: respective local boards. Dr. Bridges, SRS CAB Chair, introduced the following
label: BODY

text: top three issues for SRS: 1)Concern for the Effective Utilization of H-Canyon, 2)Concern for Prioritization
label: BODY

text: of Site Activities in view of Likely Budget Cuts, and 3) Resolve the Major Legacy of Nuclear Weapon Pro-
label: BODY

text: duction at SRS by Treating and Disposing of Liquid Waste and Closing Tanks.
label: BODY

text: Dr. Donald Bridges, pictured
label: BODY

text: right, attended the June 2011
label: BODY

text: EMSSAB Chairs’ Meeting with
label: BODY

text: Strategic & Legacy Manage-
label: BODY

text: ment Chair, Dr. Gerald Wadley,
label: BODY

text: The Board Welcomes Back Patrick McGuire as co-DDFO
label: BODY

text: In July 2011, The SRS CAB welcomed newly appointed co-Deputy Des-
label: BODY

text: ignated Federal Officer (DDFO), Pat McGuire. Mr. McGuire is no
label: BODY

text: stranger to the CAB-he has always been a regular attendee of CAB
label: BODY

text: meetings and served as a DDFO previously. He will serve as co-DDFO
label: BODY

text: for two years. Serving with Mr. McGuire is co-DDFO Doug Hintze, who
label: BODY

text: will be rotating out of this role next year.
label: BODY

text: DOE-SR has encouraged its Assistant Managers to serve on a two-year
label: BODY

text: rotational assignment as co-DDFOs for the CAB. This practice has
label: BODY

text: served to acquaint and sensitize these senior managers to the needs
label: BODY

text: and requests of our CAB members and the general public.
label: BODY

text: Patrick McGuire, DOE-SR
label: BODY

text: Patrick W. (Pat) McGuire was named the Assistant Manager for the Nuclear Material Stabili-
label: BODY

text: zation Project for the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) Savannah River Operations Office
label: BODY

text: (SR) at the Savannah River Site (SRS) in June 2007.  In this role, he provides overall leader-
label: BODY

text: ship and direction for oversight of Federal and contractor nuclear material stabilization pro-
label: BODY

text: ject activities in support of Environmental Management (EM) risk reduction and cleanup mis-
label: BODY

text: sion performed at SRS.
label: BODY

text: Prior to assuming his new role, Mr. McGuire served as the Director of the DOE-SR Nuclear
label: BODY

text: Material Programs Division since 2004, where he directed all programmatic, technical and
label: BODY

text: environmental compliance activities associated with the receipt, transportation, storage and
label: BODY

text: stabilization of Spent Nuclear Fuel, Uranium, Plutonium, and other special nuclear materials.
label: BODY

text: Karen Guevara, DOE-SR
label: BODY

text: We are always grateful to the outgoing DDFO for the valu-
label: BODY

text: able commitment of time and efforts they consistently
label: BODY

text: show  to the CAB program and members, and for that, we
label: BODY

text: are truly indebted to Karen Guevara for her tireless ser-
label: BODY

text: vice as co-DDFO over the past two years. Thank you, Ka-
label: BODY

text: ren!
label: BODY

text: The Savannah River Site (SRS) Citizens Advisory Board (CAB) met for its annual Education & Process Ses-
label: BODY

text: sion on October 12-13, in Hilton Head, South Carolina. The Board’s newest members met for an additional
label: BODY

text: day on October 11. The Education & Process Session is an administrative meeting that ensures the Board is
label: BODY

text: up-to-date on Environmental Management Site Specific Advisory Board (EMSSAB) guidelines and Board
label: BODY

text: procedures. Educational presentations are given and all members take part in process exercises. The goal
label: BODY

text: is for the CAB to leave this meeting every year feeling more confident in its role of developing recommenda-
label: BODY

text: tions in regard to SRS activities from the public’s perspective.
label: BODY

text: The SRS CAB Masters Processes During its “Education & Process Session”
label: BODY

text: WASHINGTON, DC - DOE recently announced next steps for the Asset Revitaliza-
label: BODY

text: tion Initiative (ARI), a Department-wide initiative to examine ways to work with local
label: BODY

text: communities to support the reuse of DOE resources around the country.  These
label: BODY

text: steps build on the recommendations from the Task Force on Asset Revitalization and
label: BODY

text: will facilitate local efforts to support beneficial reuse options at DOE sites, including
label: BODY

text: reindustrialization, manufacturing, clean energy development, nature preserves, and
label: BODY

text: educational centers.
label: BODY

text: Under Phase II, representatives from across DOE will continue to work together to
label: BODY

text: support the review, coordination and acceleration of asset revitalization and beneficial
label: BODY

text: reuse efforts for former DOE assets. Helen Belencan, DOE-SR, is the local repre-
label: BODY

text: sentative to the Asset Revitalization Initiative Taskforce and reports to the CAB regu-
label: BODY

text: larly on DOE and SRS asset revitalization efforts.
label: BODY

text: The Department has a successful record to date in pursuing asset revitalization, in-
label: BODY

text: cluding reducing the legacy cleanup footprint by over 2,585 square miles.  From 1996 to the present, DOE
label: BODY

text: has transferred over 8,000 acres of property that have been used to build industrial parks, research and
label: BODY

text: demonstration centers, food processing facilities, training centers, parks and recreational facilities, and con-
label: BODY

text: servation sites.
label: BODY

text: Phase II of the Taskforce will focus on specific steps to help advance these strategies and recommenda-
label: BODY

text: tions.
label: BODY

text: What is Asset Revitalization?
label: BODY

text: As of September 30, 2011, the end of most of the Recovery Act
label: BODY

text: projects, the Savannah River Site (SRS) had reached a 73 per-
label: BODY

text: cent footprint reduction, transforming nearly 228 square miles
label: BODY

text: from contaminated structures and locales to environmentally
label: BODY

text: safe assets. This milestone sends SRS well on the way to ful-
label: BODY

text: filling its 75 percent footprint reduction commitment.
label: BODY

text: The $1.6 billion in Recovery Act funding at SRS fueled more
label: BODY

text: than 3,000 jobs and nearly a half a billion dollars in contracts,
label: BODY

text: providing resources for approximately 120 projects beginning in
label: BODY

text: April 2009. The most recent of these projects to be completed by
label: BODY

text: Savannah River Nuclear Solutions (SRNS) was the reclaiming of P and R Areas, which was finished five
label: BODY

text: years ahead of schedule, netted nearly 63 square miles in footprint reduction, and marked the official end
label: BODY

text: to the areas that housed the Cold War icons, P and R Reactors. These areas are now environmentally
label: BODY

text: safe, and the two Cold War reactors are the first reactors in the DOE Complex to reach their in-situ end
label: BODY

text: state.
label: BODY

text: More than 500 regulatory milestones were achieved on or ahead of
label: BODY

text: schedule at the P and R Area Operable Units (PAOU, RAOU).
label: BODY

text: SRNS began footprint reduction across the Site early in the Recov-
label: BODY

text: ery Act. Although massive resources were directed to P and R Are-
label: BODY

text: as since 2009, Area Completion Projects were being worked on
label: BODY

text: concurrently and with equal vigor, safely contributing to SRS’ com-
label: BODY

text: mitment to DOE and the nation. Some of these notable projects in-
label: BODY

text: clude the following:
label: BODY

text: M Area, which spanned 45 acres and included a reactor fuel
label: BODY

text: manufacturing area. In October 2010, M Area was the first oper-
label: BODY

text: able unit to be closed under the Recovery Act at SRS.
label: BODY

text: The deactivation and decommissioning of the Heavy Water Components Test Reactor (HWCTR) was
label: BODY

text: completed in June 2011.
label: BODY

text: The 455 foot K Reactor Cooling Tower was imploded in May 2010.
label: BODY

text: The Site’s Accelerated transuranic (TRU) program continues to ship legacy TRU waste for permanent dis-
label: BODY

text: position at the Waste Isolation Pilot Plant (WIPP) in Carlsbad, N.M. Since the inception of the Recovery
label: BODY

text: Act in early 2009, the TRU program has shipped 2,000 cubic meters to WIPP and will continue to do so
label: BODY

text: until the 5,000-cubic-meter inventory has left the Site.
label: BODY

text: Of the $1.6 billion in Recovery Act funds, $200 million was directed to reduce the operation risk of the
label: BODY

text: Site’s liquid waste program. These projects provided infrastructure modifications and equipment needed to
label: BODY

text: prepare waste tanks for closure, to support sludge and salt waste removal, and to facilitate continued
label: BODY

text: waste processing.
label: BODY

text: For more information on the Recovery Act, including information about progress made at
label: BODY

text: SRS, please go to: srs.gov/recovery
label: BODY

text: Catching Up with the Recovery Act
label: BODY

text: Provided by Savannah River Remediation and Savannah River Nuclear Solutions
label: BODY

text: K Cooling Tower demolition in May 2010.
label: BODY

text: HWCTR dome removal.
label: BODY

text: On September 29, 2011, SRS celebrated the P & R Area Completion  under the American Recovery and
label: BODY

text: Reinvestment Act program at the Site. There were many special guests at the program, including Garry
label: BODY

text: Flowers, former CEO and President of Savannah River Nuclear Solutions (SRNS), Dwayne Wilson, the
label: BODY

text: new President of SRNS, David Huizenga, Acting Assistant Secretary for the Office of Environmental Man-
label: BODY

text: agement,  David Williams, Section Chief for EPA’s Region 4, and Robert King, Deputy Commissioner for
label: BODY

text: SCDHEC Environmental Quality Control.
label: BODY

text: The event also marked the introduction of the SRS Strategic Plan, otherwise known as Enterprise SRS,
label: BODY

text: and Dr. David Moody, SRS Site Manager, presented a video about the past and future of SRS, outlining
label: BODY

text: future missions and commitments for the Site.
label: BODY

text: SRS Commemorates P & R Reactor Area Closure
label: BODY

text: Judy
label: BODY

text: Greene-McLeod,
label: BODY

text: CAB
label: BODY

text: Vice
label: BODY

text: Chair, was invited to attend the P & R
label: BODY

text: Area Completion Celebration.
label: BODY

text: Garry Flowers, SRNS, presented David
label: BODY

text: Huizenga, DOE-HQ, with a framed photo
label: BODY

text: commemorating the P & R Area Comple-
label: BODY

text: tion.
label: BODY

text: Dr. David Moody, Site Manager,
label: BODY

text: spoke about the Site’s future
label: BODY

text: during the celebration.
label: BODY

text: The SRS Strategic Plan, otherwise known as the Enterprise SRS,
label: BODY

text: was introduced to the public at the September 27 SRS CAB Full
label: BODY

text: Board meeting in Charleston, SC. According to a DOE Press Re-
label: BODY

text: lease, this document outlines the “commitment of site leadership to
label: BODY

text: develop future missions for SRS.” Dr. Dave Moody, Site Manager,
label: BODY

text: announced during his presentation at the September Full Board that
label: BODY

text: “SRS continues its heritage of national service through environmental
label: BODY

text: stewardship, nonproliferation, and national security,” and that the En-
label: BODY

text: terprise SRS “seeks to use the knowledge of our nuclear materials workforce, Site assets, and the strength
label: BODY

text: of the Savannah River National Laboratory to address the nation’s pressing issues.” He said SRS leader-
label: BODY

text: ship is committed to moving forward with the Enterprise SRS vision, and plans to pursue top priority objec-
label: BODY

text: tives, re-shape cultural, organizational, and business practices, and build strong business and inter-agency
label: BODY

text: support networks.
label: BODY

text: To review the 2011 SRS Strategic Plan:http://www.srs.gov/general/pubs srs_2011strategic_plan.pdf
label: BODY

text: A Plan for the Future of the Savannah River Site: Enterprise SRS
label: BODY

text: Disposition Path: Those activities that follow generation of a waste and which con-
label: BODY

text: stitute completion of a life cycle of management of a waste, including but not limited
label: BODY

text: to, stabilization, deactivation, disposal, decommissioning, dismantlement, and/or re-
label: BODY

text: use. The end state is where the item under discussion will no longer require some
label: BODY

text: form of additional work/efforts to place in a safe and appropriate state.
label: BODY

text: Terms and Phrases You May Hear at an SRS CAB Meeting
label: BODY

text: Operable Unit: Operable unit, as defined in the National Oil and Hazardous Sub-
label: BODY

text: stances Pollution Coningency Plan, is a discrete action that comprises an incremen-
label: BODY

text: tal step toward comprehensively addressing site problems. This discrete portion of a
label: BODY

text: remedial response manages migration, or eliminates or mitigates a release, threat of
label: BODY

text: release, or pathway of exposure. The cleanup of a large site such as SRS can be
label: BODY

text: divided into a number of operable units. Operable units at SRS are defined geo-
label: BODY

text: graphically –that is, they are separate waste units (where an actual or potential re-
label: BODY

text: lease of hazardous substance is located) that may be small and isolated, or large Ar-
label: BODY

text: ea Operable Units consolidating several potential release sites, or an entire stream
label: BODY

text: system (Integrator Operable Unit). SRS Operable Units are listed in Appendix C of
label: BODY

text: the Federal Facility Agreement for the Savannah River Site
label: BODY

text: Transuranic (TRU) Waste: TRU  wastes are discarded materials that have been
label: BODY

text: generated from nuclear weapons production, research, and development since the
label: BODY

text: 1950s.TRU waste is contaminated with man-made radioactive materials with atomic
label: BODY

text: numbers greater than uranium, such as plutonium, americium, and curium. TRU
label: BODY

text: waste is officially defined as waste contaminated with alpha-emitting radionuclides,
label: BODY

text: having atomic numbers greater than 92 and with half-lives greater than 20 years in
label: BODY

text: concentrations greater than 100 nanocuries per gram of waste. These wastes include
label: BODY

text: such materials as laboratory clothing, rubber gloves, tools, glove boxes, glassware,
label: BODY

text: piping, air filters, plastics, wood, metals, and solidified waste water sludges contami-
label: BODY

text: nated with TRU materials.
label: BODY

text: Record of Decision (ROD): The ROD is a public document that explains which
label: BODY

text: cleanup alternatives will be used to clean up a Superfund site. A ROD contains site
label: BODY

text: history, site description, site characteristics, community participation, enforcement
label: BODY

text: activities, past and present activities, contaminated media, the contaminants present,
label: BODY

text: scope and role of response action, the remedy selected for cleanup, and any long-
label: BODY

text: term maintenance and monitoring requirements associated with it.
label: BODY

text: Superfund: Superfund is another name for the Comprehensive Environmental Re-
label: BODY

text: sponse, Compensation, and Liability Act (CERCLA), the federal government’s pro-
label: BODY

text: gram to clean up the nation’s hazardous waste sites. The Superfund clean up pro-
label: BODY

text: cess is complex. It involves the steps taken to assess the sites, places them on the
label: BODY

text: National Priorities List, and establishes , and implements, appropriate cleanup plans.
label: BODY

text: Cleanup under Superfund, or CERCLA, is overseen by EPA and typically a state
label: BODY

text: cleanup authority.
label: BODY

text: Spent Nuclear Fuel (SNF): SNF is also referred to as Used Nuclear Fuel (UNF).
label: BODY

text: It is nuclear fuel that has been irradiated in a nuclear reactor, usually at a commercial
label: BODY

text: nuclear power plant. SNF at SRS is typically from research reactors. It is no longer
label: BODY

text: useful in sustaining a nuclear reaction.
label: BODY

text: Public comment periods are offered at all CAB meetings. When requested in writing, the Department of
label: BODY

text: Energy responds to public comments. At Combined Committee and Full Board meetings, there are two
label: BODY

text: that community members wanting to participate in the public comment process should notice.
label: BODY

text: There is a yellow form, used for requesting written responses from DOE. Responses from DOE will be
label: BODY

text: delivered in as timely a fashion as possible. Community members who submit written public comments
label: BODY

text: can typically expect a response from DOE within 30 to 60 days. These forms are also available at commit-
label: BODY

text: tee meetings.
label: BODY

text: During Full Board meetings, some community members in attendance may wish to sign-up to make public
label: BODY

text: comments. A pink sign-up sheet used to make public comments is always made available on a table at
label: BODY

text: the back of the meeting alongside presentations, newsletters, and other materials. Typically, there are
label: BODY

text: three to five public comment periods offered. The public can sign-up for as many public comment periods
label: BODY

text: as desired. However, there will be no response made to public comments from DOE or CAB members at
label: BODY

text: the meeting.  If the sign-up sheet cannot be found, please alert a member of the CAB Support Team.  The-
label: BODY

text: se forms are not used at CAB committee meetings. The public is invited to make comments, but since
label: BODY

text: committee meetings are less formal, Committee Chairs will announce public comment periods.
label: BODY

text: How to Make a Public Comment to the SRS CAB
label: BODY

text: This form is used to request responses from
label: BODY

text: DOE to public comments.
label: BODY

text: This form is used to sign-in to make
label: BODY

text: public comments at CAB Combined
label: BODY

text: Committee and Full Board meetings.
label: BODY

text: Check out the SRS CAB’s Website at cab.srs.gov
label: BODY

text: The Savannah River Site (SRS) Citizens Advisory Board (CAB) website is a great resource for anyone who
label: BODY

text: wants to say up-to-date on CAB Recommendations, activities, meetings, and more.
label: BODY

text: You’ll find presentations from meetings, a Recommendation Database, meeting summaries and minutes,
label: BODY

text: online meetings, public comments, member bios, the CAB’s Charter, plus more, on the CAB’s website. All
label: BODY

text: materials are available for download and printing.
label: BODY

text: If you would like to be added to the CAB’s email distribution list, send your name, number, and email to:
label: BODY

text: srscitizensadvisoryboard@srs.gov
label: BODY

text: Washington, D.C. -- The U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) announced that the first shipment of
label: BODY

text: transuranic waste using the newly approved shipping package known as the TRUPACT-III safely
label: BODY

text: arrived at the Waste Isolation Pilot Plant (WIPP) near Carlsbad, New Mexico.
label: BODY

text: The shipment, which originated at the Savannah River Site (SRS) in South Carolina, arrived at
label: BODY

text: WIPP on August 25. The new shipping package – the Transuranic Package Transporter Model 3
label: BODY

text: or TRUPACT-III – allows the Department to package and ship large-sized transuranic waste in a
label: BODY

text: single box that would otherwise have to be broken down into smaller waste boxes. This new ship-
label: BODY

text: ping package will help accelerate the pace of
label: BODY

text: cleanup at sites across the country, while reduc-
label: BODY

text: ing risk to worker safety.
label: BODY

text: “This announcement is a clear example of how
label: BODY

text: ongoing innovations within the Environmental
label: BODY

text: Management program are helping to increase the
label: BODY

text: efficiency of our operations, speed our cleanup
label: BODY

text: efforts at Cold War sites across the country, and
label: BODY

text: improve safety,” said Dave Huizenga, DOE’s Act-
label: BODY

text: ing Assistant Secretary for Environmental Man-
label: BODY

text: agement.
label: BODY

text: Transuranic waste consists of materials such as
label: BODY

text: clothing, tools, rags, residues, soil, debris, and oth-
label: BODY

text: er materials contaminated with plutonium or other
label: BODY

text: hazardous chemicals.
label: BODY

text: The TRUPACT-III shipping package allows the loading of large-sized transuranic waste into a sin-
label: BODY

text: gle box, instead of repackaging it into smaller waste boxes. This will allow for faster processing
label: BODY

text: and shipping, while significantly reducing the chance of potential exposure to the workers that are
label: BODY

text: preparing the waste to be shipped to WIPP.
label: BODY

text: The TRUPACT-III will be used to ship large box waste at SRS as part of the site’s American Re-
label: BODY

text: covery and Reinvestment Act work to complete its legacy transuranic waste program. In the fu-
label: BODY

text: ture, the TRUPACT-III may also be used at other sites that have large transuranic box waste,
label: BODY

text: such as the Hanford Site in Washington State, the Idaho National Laboratory, and the Los Ala-
label: BODY

text: mos National Laboratory in New Mexico. Large-sized transuranic waste includes contaminated
label: BODY

text: glove boxes, used motors, and large-scale analytical equipment.
label: BODY

text: The design and manufacturing of the TRUPACT-III was completed with $12 million in funding
label: BODY

text: from the Recovery Act. WIPP is a DOE facility designed to safely dispose of legacy transuranic
label: BODY

text: waste from the Cold War to protect people and the environment. Transuranic waste is permanent-
label: BODY

text: ly disposed in rooms mined out of a salt formation 2,150 feet below the surface. WIPP, which be-
label: BODY

text: gan waste disposal operations in 1999, is located 26 miles outside of Carlsbad, New Mexico.
label: BODY

text: First TRUPACT-III Shipment Arrives Safely at the
label: BODY

text: Waste Isolation Pilot Plant (WIPP)
label: BODY

text: Originally published by the Office of Environmental Management-Washington, DC
label: BODY

text: The TRUPACT-III is a new TRU waste transpor-
label: BODY

text: tation package now in use for shipments to
label: BODY

text: WIPP.
label: BODY

text: “On September 29, I had the opportunity to attend an
label: BODY

text: Environmental Justice (EJ) Workshop that was spon-
label: BODY

text: sored by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) in
label: BODY

text: Barnwell, SC. I understood the purpose of this workshop
label: BODY

text: as a way to enlighten the general population on
label: BODY

text: “Environmental Justice,” and to inform them about what
label: BODY

text: resources are available. It was a wonderful, educational
label: BODY

text: meeting for the community. I noticed many surrounding
label: BODY

text: communities were represented at the meeting, with pub-
label: BODY

text: lic members present from areas such as Barnwell, Willis-
label: BODY

text: ton, Elko, Denmark, and Blackville.
label: BODY

text: For me, the highlight of the workshop was the up-
label: BODY

text: dates on the progress of the Superfund Job Train-
label: BODY

text: ing Initiative (Super JTI). EPA is working with Par-
label: BODY

text: sons on a third session of Super JTI. The gradu-
label: BODY

text: ates of the program, referred to as “scholars,” were
label: BODY

text: on-hand to give testimonials of their experiences in
label: BODY

text: the program, as well as their successes. Two
label: BODY

text: scholars gave insight into their journey to employ-
label: BODY

text: ment at Savannah River Site.
label: BODY

text: As a CAB member, and a member of the public, I was very impressed with the
label: BODY

text: presentations given at the meeting, and the attendance. I believe if we continue
label: BODY

text: to educate the communities on environmental issues, those communities will be-
label: BODY

text: come empowered.”
label: BODY

text: Environmental Justice Meeting Held in Barnwell on September 29
label: BODY

text: By: Denise Long, CAB Member
label: BODY

text: Kristin
label: BODY

text: Major,
label: BODY

text: TechLaw,
label: BODY

text: helps make the EJ Program
label: BODY

text: a success.
label: BODY

text: A Super JTI Scholar tells
label: BODY

text: the audience about his
label: BODY

text: experiences
label: BODY

text: with
label: BODY

text: the
label: BODY

text: program.
label: BODY

text: Rob Pope, EPA, gives a
label: BODY

text: presentation on what is going
label: BODY

text: on at SRS.
label: BODY

text: Kyle Bryant, EPA, answers
label: BODY

text: questions from the audi-
label: BODY

text: ence.
label: BODY

text: Cate Alexander, DOE Headquarters, Comes to Charleston to Speak to the SRS CAB
label: BODY

text: Cate Alexander,  Designated Federal Officer of the Environmental Manage-
label: BODY

text: ment Site Specific Advisory Board ( EM SSAB), presented at the September
label: BODY

text: 26 CAB Combined Committee meeting, held in Charleston, SC. Ms. Alexan-
label: BODY

text: der offered insight and knowledge on how EM SSABs operate, and what the
label: BODY

text: CAB’s role is at Savannah River Site (SRS). Her presentation focused on
label: BODY

text: an overview of the Federal Advisory Committee Act (FACA), including the
label: BODY

text: responsibilities and authority given to the Department of Energy (DOE), in-
label: BODY

text: formation that members of EM SSABs need to know, and DOE Headquar-
label: BODY

text: ters' views on the EM SSAB.
label: BODY

text: While providing guidance on membership, Ms. Alexander spoke on commit-
label: BODY

text: tee management, the Federal Register, the DOE Manual, and other key fac-
label: BODY

text: tors that influence who is chosen for board membership. She offered key
label: BODY

text: points for a balanced membership, and reviewed the responsibilities of Ad-
label: BODY

text: visory Board members. Overall, the presentation was very informative and
label: BODY

text: helped many members better understand their role on the CAB.
label: BODY

text: Much appreciation is extended to Ms. Alexander!
label: BODY

text: Cate Alexander, DFO EM SSAB,
label: BODY

text: came up to the mic after her
label: BODY

text: presentation to answer questions.
label: BODY

text: Two Savannah River Site Projects Gain National Recognition
label: BODY

text: Republished from a DOE-SR Press Release
label: BODY

text: AIKEN, SC – The Department of Energy’s Savannah River Site has received Environmental Sustainability
label: BODY

text: (EStar) awards from DOE for two projects growing out of technology research, development and applica-
label: BODY

text: tion at the Savannah River National Laboratory.
label: BODY

text: The EStar awards recognize excellence in pollution prevention and sustainable environmental steward-
label: BODY

text: ship.  They are awarded for projects and programs that reduce environmental impacts, enhance site oper-
label: BODY

text: ations, and reduce costs.
label: BODY

text: One award, for Renewable Technology Development, Deployment and Education in South Carolina,
label: BODY

text: is a collaboration between SRNL and the Economic Development Partnership of South Carolina.  Through
label: BODY

text: collaboration, SRNL has shared expertise and knowledge of renewable energy technologies with EDP,
label: BODY

text: which in turn has leveraged existing relationships with industry to identify and evaluate specific opportuni-
label: BODY

text: ties.  The results have ranged from emissions reductions (through deployment and staging of hydrogen
label: BODY

text: and wind energy technology) to community education programs.
label: BODY

text: The second award recognized a project to remediate tritium-contaminated debris in an innovative,
label: BODY

text: cost-effective way.  SRNL identified and tested technology to remove tritium from contaminated concrete
label: BODY

text: and soil by using a high heat source called a “thermal detritiation unit.”  Each unit is a concrete block struc-
label: BODY

text: ture housing an array of commercially available heating elements, effectively removing the tritium over a
label: BODY

text: period of time.  The treated soil and concrete debris can be disposed at an on-site excavation site rather
label: BODY

text: than sent offsite for disposal, reducing transportation, packaging and disposal costs.  Over $1.6 million in
label: BODY

text: transportation cost savings and an avoidance of 400,000 truck miles were realized from the deployment.
label: BODY

text: “These awards are hard to get, and we can all be justifiably proud that SRS has been recognized in this
label: BODY

text: way,” said Dr. David Moody, manager of the Department of Energy’s Savannah River office.  “This calls
label: BODY

text: attention to the value of our National Laboratory as a technology engine, and the expertise we have in
label: BODY

text: dealing with challenging cleanup issues.  Both of these projects represent valuable contributions not only
label: BODY

text: to the site, but to the region and to other DOE complex sites.”
label: BODY

text: DOE’s Steve Mackmull is the federal lead for the site’s Pollution Prevention program.  John Harley of Sa-
label: BODY

text: vannah River Nuclear Solutions is the lead for the contractor organization. The awards are among 15
label: BODY

text: granted by DOE out of 186 national entries.
label: BODY

text: NNSA Announces H-Canyon to Support Plutonium Disposition at the Savannah River Site
label: BODY

text: Republished from a NNSA Press Release
label: BODY

text: WASHINGTON, D.C. – The National Nuclear Security
label: BODY

text: Administration (NNSA) this week approved the use of
label: BODY

text: the H-Canyon Complex to provide approximately 3.7 MT
label: BODY

text: of plutonium oxide feed for the MOX Fuel Fabrication
label: BODY

text: Facility from the non-pit plutonium currently stored at
label: BODY

text: Savannah River Site (SRS). The use of the H-Canyon
label: BODY

text: Complex will result in the retention of approximately 90
label: BODY

text: high-quality jobs in South Carolina, and demonstrates
label: BODY

text: NNSA’s commitment to remove plutonium from the
label: BODY

text: state.
label: BODY

text: “This joint effort between NNSA and DOE’s Office of En-
label: BODY

text: vironmental Management helps us implement President
label: BODY

text: Obama’s nuclear security agenda while keeping 90 high-quality jobs in South Carolina,” said NNSA Ad-
label: BODY

text: ministrator Thomas D’Agostino. “This decision will help us dispose of surplus weapons-grade plutonium
label: BODY

text: while also investing in our current infrastructure at the Savannah River Site.”
label: BODY

text: H-Canyon and HB-Line will initiate start-up preparations for plutonium oxide production in FY 2012. In its
label: BODY

text: next full year of operation, it is estimated that H-Canyon will produce approximately 200 kg of plutonium
label: BODY

text: oxide, and ramp up to a full production rate of up to 1 MT per year in FY 2015. NNSA’s Office of Defense
label: BODY

text: Nuclear Nonproliferation will fund the incremental operating cost to perform this work and has identified the
label: BODY

text: estimated $20.5 million per year of funds needed in FY 2012. This decision will result in a cost-effective
label: BODY

text: approach for producing plutonium oxide for the MOX Facility that utilizes current resources and capabili-
label: BODY

text: ties.
label: BODY

text: Through the Plutonium Management and Disposition Agreement (PMDA), the U.S. and Russia have
label: BODY

text: agreed to each dispose of at least 34 metric tons of surplus weapon-grade plutonium, enough total materi-
label: BODY

text: al for approximately 17,000 nuclear weapons. To implement plutonium disposition in the United States,
label: BODY

text: NNSA is building the MOX Fuel Fabrication Facility to fabricate the plutonium feedstock into MOX fuel.
label: BODY

text: H-Canyon, located at SRS, is the only hardened nucle-
label: BODY

text: ar chemical separations plant still in operation in the
label: BODY

text: U.S.
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: H-Canyon was constructed in the early 1950s and be-
label: BODY

text: gan operations in 1955. It is the only hardened nuclear
label: BODY

text: chemical operations plant still in operation in the United
label: BODY

text: States. The facility’s operations historically recovered
label: BODY

text: uranium-235 (U-235), and neptunium-237 (Np-237) from
label: BODY

text: aluminum-clad enriched-uranium fuel tubes from site
label: BODY

text: nuclear reactors and other domestic and foreign re-
label: BODY

text: search reactors using a chemical separations process.
label: BODY

text: Since 1996, the L-Area Complex has received about
label: BODY

text: 10,400 UNF assemblies in 506 casks from off-site
label: BODY

text: sources. Underwater storage facilities, called disassem-
label: BODY

text: bly basins, were located in all five SRS production reac-
label: BODY

text: tor areas. These facilities were designed to store UNF
label: BODY

text: and
label: BODY

text: target
label: BODY

text: assemblies discharged from the reactor cores. This
label: BODY

text: storage allowed the nuclear materials to cool after
label: BODY

text: being irradiated in the reactors. The basins were al-
label: BODY

text: so used to prepare the nuclear materials for
label: BODY

text: transport to the F and H area processing facilities. In
label: BODY

text: 1996, L-Basin equipment was reconfigured to safely
label: BODY

text: handle and store UNF from off-site research reac-
label: BODY

text: tors. By 2003, L-Basin was SRS’s only fuel receipt
label: BODY

text: and storage facility.
label: BODY

text: On October 25, 2011, Several CAB members, along
label: BODY

text: with a representative from EPA and Pat McGuire,
label: BODY

text: DOE-SR, attended a tour of H-Canyon and L-Basin.
label: BODY

text: The tour was very extensive, with the participants being
label: BODY

text: provided overviews of the Spent Nuclear Fuel Program
label: BODY

text: and the Nuclear Materials Disposition Process.
label: BODY

text: The tour took CAB members through L-Basin, showing
label: BODY

text: storage models, presenting a handling tool demonstra-
label: BODY

text: tion and a fuel type “show and tell.” The tour concluded
label: BODY

text: at H-Canyon, where members were able to view the
label: BODY

text: control room, the crane room, and roof top. All of the site
label: BODY

text: subject matter experts were eager to help, and ensured
label: BODY

text: all questions were answered.
label: BODY

text: The CAB Attends an H-Canyon and L-Area Tour at SRS
label: BODY

text: Historical data provided by SRNS L-Area and H-Canyon fact sheets
label: BODY

text: The CAB  members took a moment to take a picture
label: BODY

text: in front of H-Canyon. H-Canyon has been a major
label: BODY

text: topic of concern in 2011 for  the CAB
label: BODY

text: One of the many helpful subject matter experts
label: BODY

text: gave a fuel  type show and tell.
label: BODY

text: Outside of H-Canyon, the CAB members were given a very
label: BODY

text: informative  tool demonstration.
